question: Which cranial nerve gives rise to the ophthalmic division (CN V1)?
short_explanation: CN V1 is the first division of the trigeminal nerve.
long_explanation: The ophthalmic division is the first and most superior branch of the trigeminal nerve (CN V), which is the primary sensory nerve of the face.
applied_example: Pain above the eye or forehead may be linked to CN V1 irritation or herpes zoster ophthalmicus.
text: Which cranial nerve gives rise to the ophthalmic division (CN V1)?

question: Which type of fibers does CN V1 primarily carry?
short_explanation: CN V1 carries only sensory fibers.
long_explanation: The ophthalmic division of CN V is purely sensory and does not carry motor fibers. It transmits sensations like touch, pain, and temperature from the upper face.
applied_example: A loss of corneal reflex may indicate damage to the sensory input via CN V1.
text: Which type of fibers does CN V1 primarily carry?

question: Through which foramen does CN V1 enter the orbit?
short_explanation: CN V1 passes through the superior orbital fissure.
long_explanation: After branching from the trigeminal ganglion, CN V1 enters the orbit via the superior orbital fissure, accompanying other nerves and vessels supplying the eye.
applied_example: Trauma to the orbit may compromise nerves traveling through the superior orbital fissure, including CN V1.
text: Through which foramen does CN V1 enter the orbit?

question: Which of the following is NOT a branch of CN V1?
short_explanation: The buccal nerve is a branch of CN V3.
long_explanation: The ophthalmic division divides into three main branches: frontal, lacrimal, and nasociliary. The buccal nerve is instead a sensory branch of the mandibular division (V3).
applied_example: Knowing the branches helps target specific nerves during facial pain assessment or sinus pressure work.
text: Which of the following is NOT a branch of CN V1?

question: Which facial region receives sensory innervation from CN V1?
short_explanation: CN V1 innervates the forehead and upper eyelid.
long_explanation: The ophthalmic division provides sensation to the scalp, forehead, upper eyelid, cornea, and dorsum of the nose via its branches.
applied_example: Facial massage involving the forehead may stimulate sensory input from CN V1.
text: Which facial region receives sensory innervation from CN V1?

question: Which reflex uses CN V1 as its afferent limb?
short_explanation: CN V1 carries sensory input from the cornea for the blink reflex.
long_explanation: The corneal reflex involves CN V1 as the sensory (afferent) limb and CN VII (facial nerve) as the motor (efferent) limb, resulting in blinking when the cornea is touched.
applied_example: Testing this reflex can help differentiate between CN V and CN VII pathology.
text: Which reflex uses CN V1 as its afferent limb?

question: Which CN V1 branch travels with the supraorbital artery to the forehead?
short_explanation: The supraorbital nerve accompanies the artery through the supraorbital notch.
long_explanation: The supraorbital nerve is a terminal branch of the frontal nerve, itself a branch of CN V1, and innervates the forehead and scalp.
applied_example: Compression near the eyebrow can cause numbness or tingling due to supraorbital nerve impingement.
text: Which CN V1 branch travels with the supraorbital artery to the forehead?

question: Herpes zoster ophthalmicus is a reactivation of VZV in which cranial nerve branch?
short_explanation: It affects the ophthalmic branch of the trigeminal nerve.
long_explanation: Herpes zoster ophthalmicus is a painful condition resulting from reactivation of latent varicella-zoster virus in CN V1, particularly affecting the eye and forehead.
applied_example: Massage therapists should avoid facial work during an active VZV outbreak.
text: Herpes zoster ophthalmicus is a reactivation of VZV in which cranial nerve branch?

question: The nasociliary nerve, a branch of CN V1, supplies which structure?
short_explanation: The nasociliary nerve supplies sensation to the skin on the dorsum and tip of the nose.
long_explanation: It also provides sensory fibers to the eye, ethmoid sinuses, and skin at the root of the nose, making it an important nerve in nasal trauma or infection.
applied_example: Swelling or trauma near the nose may affect the nasociliary branch and sensory input.
text: The nasociliary nerve, a branch of CN V1, supplies which structure?

question: The lacrimal nerve carries sensory input from which structure?
short_explanation: It carries sensation from the lacrimal gland and upper lateral eyelid.
long_explanation: The lacrimal nerve is the smallest branch of CN V1 and runs along the lateral wall of the orbit to supply the lacrimal gland, conjunctiva, and skin of the upper eyelid.
applied_example: Dry eye symptoms may have sensory input from the lacrimal nerve pathway.
text: The lacrimal nerve carries sensory input from which structure?
abcd: B. Lacrimal gland and upper eyelid
